Graphical abstract Two types of heterogeneous catalytic materials, MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox, have been synthesized and compared by covalent grafting of a catalytically active [MnII-L3imid] complex on the surface of an oxidized activated carbon (Cox) and an oxidized pyrolytic carbon from recycled-tire char (PCox). Both hybrids are non-porous bearing graphitic layers intermixed with disordered sp2/sp3 carbon units. Raman spectra show that (ID/IG)activatedcarbon >(ID/IG)pyrolyticcarbon revealing that oxidized activated carbon(Cox) is less graphitized than oxidized pyrolytic carbon (PCox). The MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox catalysts were evaluated for alkene oxidation with H2O2 in the presence of CH3COONH4. Both showed high selectivity towards epoxides and comparing the achieved yields and TONs, they appear equivalent. However, MnII-L3imid@PCox catalyst is kinetically faster than the MnII-L3imid@Cox (accomplishing the catalytic runs in 1.5h vs. 5h). Thus, despite the similarity in TONs MnII-L3imid@PCox achieved extremely higher TOFs vs. MnII-L3imid@Cox. Intriguingly, in terms of recyclability, MnII-L3imid@Cox could be reused for a 2th run showing a ∼20% loss of its catalytic activity, while MnII-L3imid@PCox practically no recyclable. This phenomenon is discussed in a mechanistic context; interlinking oxidative destruction of the Mn-complex with high TOFs for MnII-L3imid@PCox, while the low-TOFs of MnII-L3imid@Cox are preventive for the oxidative destruction of the Mn-complex. Keywords Mn(II) catalysts Covalent immobilization H2O2 Catalytic epoxidation Activated Pyrolytic carbon 1 Introduction In nature, manganese can frequently be found in the catalytic redox center of several enzymes [1,2]. Mn-complexes bearing non-heme ligands i.e. such as salen-derived ligands have been promise as versatile catalysts in olefin epoxidation [3–5]. Manganese complexes of 1,4,7-triazacyclononane (tacn) or 1,4,7-trimethyl-1,4,7triazacyclononane (tmtacn) ligands, which were originally synthesized and studied as models for the oxygen evolving centre of photosystem II and for manganese catalase [6,7], were also employed as bleaching – [8] and epoxidation [9–12] – catalysts using H2O2 as oxidant. There is still great research interest for efficient non-heme Mn complexes in catalytic epoxidations of olefins [13–20]. Besides efficiency of Mn-catalysts, stability and reusability constitute equally important parameters for catalytic reactions. Thus, recovery and reuse of the used catalysts is a challenging task that has to be considered. In this context, catalyst heterogenization on a solid support provides advantages such as easy handling, easy product separation, catalyst recovery and reuse, and lower waste’s production [21–23]. A variety of carbon materials have been used as catalyst-supports in heterogeneous catalysis such as graphite, carbon black, activated carbon (C) and pyrolytic carbon (PC) [24–26]. Carbons appear to be a very flexible support since they have high surface area and high porosity [27]. It has been shown that the surface area and porosity of carbons may be important factors for the preparation of the corresponding catalysts by influencing their features properties [24,28]. Within this context, the role of surface chemistry of carbons is also determinant [28]. When oxidation takes place, the surface of carbon becomes rich in a variety of oxygen-based functional groups i.e. carboxyl, carbonyl, lactonic and phenolic, at a broad range of concentrations which depend on the method of activation, the used reagents and the temperature of the process [29–33]. These functionalities can affect the synthesis of supported catalysts onto the carbons, by controlling the acid-base and hydrophilic character of the carbon surface [34–37]. So far, heterogenization of metal complexes has been realized via their adsorption or covalent grafting on carbon surfaces [38–47]. For efficient heterogeneous catalysts via grafting of metal complexes onto carbon, the choice of the appropriate spacer group consists of another key parameter. This spacer should be bifunctional i.e. to react with both the surface groups of the carbon and the metal complex, to bridge them. Moreover spacer length, flexibility and degree of surface coverage [22,48–50] will ultimately affect the catalytic performance. In the literature, there are very few examples of Mn oxidation catalysts immobilized on carbon. More specifically, their anchoring has been achieved either via adsorption [45,46,51], axial coordination to support [44,52] or covalent attachment [44]. It is obvious that the covalent bond formation between the metal complex and the support ensures minimum catalyst leaching during catalytic process [53]. Recently [25] we have reported an efficient protocol to covalently immobilized metal complexes onto the carbon surface, by generating a [metal complex-silane] precursor which is attached to the surface OH groups of the carbon [25]. The so-obtained Mn(II) heterogeneous catalysts have been proven to be effective and selective towards epoxides with H2O2 in the presence of CH3COONH4 [25]. Moreover they presented very good reusability indicating that they are stable against oxidative destruction [25]. The same protocol has been applied very recently by our group [26] to graft Mn(II)-catalyst onto the surface of PC for oxidative degradation of methyl orange [26]. It is obvious that – due to the rapid development of automobile industry – the amount of used tires is growing continuously. Thus, to face economic, managerial, environmental issues of used tires pyrolysis is considered to be the most environmentally acceptable and promising treatment method with low pollution emission. Pyrolytic char is one of the main products obtained by the pyrolysis process and its’ applications are still being sought [54–56]. Thus, a post-production use of carbons and chars from waste tire is an attractive technology [57–63]. These materials have physical and textural characteristics similar to those of certain commercial carbon blacks [52,64]. Hence pyrolytic carbon char (PC) has great potential applicability, however so far applications in catalysis are still being scarce [26,64–66]. Here, a non-heme Mn(II) complex was covalently immobilized onto commercial activated carbon (C) and pyrolytic carbon char (PC). The Mn-complex bears a bio-inspired ligand with three imidazole moieties (L3imid). The so-derived MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox, hybrid materials have been evaluated for alkene epoxidation catalysis. The main findings of the present work are (i) the activated carbon bears more structural defects than the pyrolytic one which is smoother, (ii) both MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox, catalysts are selective towards epoxide formation and, based on the achieved yields and TONs, none shows a clear superiority, and (iii) MnII-L3imid@PCox, is kinetically faster than MnII-L3imid@Cox, (iv) higher TOFs achieved by MnII-L3imid@PCox are correlated with faster oxidative deactivation of the material. 2 Experimental Activated commercial carbon(C) was purchased from Fluka (05120). The char (pyrolytic carbon, PC) used in this work was obtained via pyrolysis of used rubber tires. All substrates were purchased from Aldrich, in their highest commercial purity, stored at 5°C and purified by passage through a column of basic alumina with methanol as the eluting solvent prior to use. Analytical grade acetone, methanol and ammonium acetate were from Aldrich and Merck respectively. Hydrogen peroxide was 30% aqueous solution. (3-glycidyloxypropyl)-trimethoxysilane was purchased from Fluka. Infrared spectra were recorded on GX Perkin-Elmer FT-IR System. Continuous-wave (c.w.) X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed with a D8 Advance Bruker X-ray diffractometer using Cu Ka radiation (k=0.154nm) as the X-ray source, scanning from 10° to 60° at a rate of 0.03°/2s for the activated carbon and from 10° to 80° at a rate of 0.02°/2s for the pyrolytic carbon. Thermogravimetric analysis were carried out with a Shimadzu, DTG-60 instrument, at a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1 and a flow rate of synthetic air gas of 50cm3 min−1. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw 1000 micro-Raman spectrometer at 532nm wavelength incident laser light. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at 77K on an Autosorb-1, Quantachrome porosimeter. Specific surfaces areas were determined with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method using adsorption data points. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was observed in a Jeol JSM 5600 system operating at 20kV. GC analysis was performed using a Shimadzu GC-17A gas chromatograph coupled with a GCMS-QP5000 mass spectrometer. Gas chromatography was performed using a SPB-5 column (30m, 0.25mm i.d, 0.25μm). The temperature program for cyclohexene, cyclooctene, styrene, limonene ((4R)-1-methyl-4-prop-1-en-2-ylcyclohexene), cyclopentene, 1-methyl-1-cyclohexene and alpha-pinene (4,6,6-trimethylbicyclo[3.1.1]hept-3-ene) was: 80°C for the first 5min, followed by a 10°Cmin−1 temperature gradient to 150°C for 5min. The temperature program for trans-β-methylstyrene ((1E)-1-propen-1-ylbenzene) and cis-stilbene ((Z)-stilbene) was: 80°C for the first 5min, followed by a 10°Cmin−1 temperature gradient to 220°C for 1min. For hex-1-ene: 50°C for the first 5min followed by a 10°Cmin−1 temperature gradient to 150°C for 5min. Injector and interface temperatures were set at 230°C and 290°C, respectively. Chromatography grade helium was used as the carrier gas, linear velocity=36.8cms−1 at column pressure 64.5kPa. 2.1 Ligand synthesis The synthesis and characterization of the L3imid ligand has been described in full detail in our previous work [18]. 2.2 Oxidation of activated carbon C and pyrolytic carbon Activation of commercial activated carbon (C) and pyrolytic carbon (PC) has been achieved by oxidation with nitric acid (HNO3) leading to the formation of surfacial carboxylic groups (COOH) [25]. 5g of C was refluxed with 90ml 65% v/v HNO3 for 6h. The oxidized carbon (Cox) obtained was separated by filtration, washed exhaustively with distilled water until pH∼7 and dried under reduced pressure at 40°C for 12h. The same procedure was employed for the oxidation of PC. Here after the obtained oxidized carbons are abbreviated as Cox (oxidized commercial activated carbon) and PCox (oxidized pyrolytic carbon). DRIFTS-IR: (cm−1, selected peaks): C: 3430: ν(OH); 2922, 2853: v(CH); 1582, 1460 ν(CC); 1167 ν(CO). Cox: 3419: v(OH); 2959, 2919, 2850: v(CH); 1715: ν(CO); 1580, 1472 ν(CC); 1176 ν(CO) (Fig. 1 .A). PC: 3438: ν(COH); 2920, 2853: ν(CH); 1632: ν(CC); 1385: ν(COH); 1105: ν(CC) (Fig. 1). PCox: 3438: v(OH); 2917, 2848: v(CH); 1704: ν(CO); 1536, 1461 ν(CC); 1382 ν(CH2 ); 1106 ν(CO) (Fig. 1B). 2.3 Synthesis of precursor silane-compounds and metalation of carbon materials 1.2mmol of L3imid and 1mmol of (3-glycidyloxypropyl)-trimethoxysilane were stirred for 24h in 40ml of MeOH at 65°C in order to generate L3imid-P silane precursor. Into this solution, 1mmol of MnCl2·4H2O dissolved in 5ml MeOH was added and the reaction mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature to form the metalled precursor MnII-L3imid-P. Then, 300mg of Cox or PCox were added and the obtained slurry solutions were refluxed at 65°C for 24h. The resulting materials MnII-L3imid@Cox or MnII-L3imid@PCox were washed several times with MeOH, EtOH and finally dried under vacuum at 40°C for 24h. MnII-L3imid@Cox: 3419: v(OH); 3218: ν(NH); 2922, 2861: v(CH); 1679: ν(CN); 1546,1458: v(CC); 1175 ν(CO) (Fig. 1A). MnII-L3imid@PCox: 3438: v(OH); 3228: ν(NH); 2917, 2848: v(CH); 1680: ν(CN); 1536, 1455 ν(CC); 1106 ν(CO) (Fig. 1B). 2.4 General procedure for catalytic epoxidation of olefins and terpenes The catalytic experiments were carried out at room temperature (25±0.5°C) with a molar ratio [catalyst: H2O2: alkene: CH3COONH4]=[1:2000:1000:1000μmol]. The standard protocol for catalytic epoxidation reactions is the following: in a solution of acetone/methanol (v/v=450μl/400μl), alkene substrate (1mmol), acetophenone or bromobenzene as internal standard (1mmol), catalyst (1μmol) and CH3COONH4 as additive (1mmol) were added. The last reagent H2O2 (2mmol) was first diluted in methanol (1:1) and then was added by a digitally controlled syringe pump [SP1011Z WPI] over 30min. The mass of the catalysts used was based on the Mn loading of MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox. The total volume of catalytic reactions was approximately 1ml. The progress of the reaction was monitored by GC–MS, by removing small amounts of the reaction mixture. To establish the identity of the epoxide products unequivocally, the retention time and spectral data were compared to those of commercial samples. Blank experiments showed that without Mn-catalyst or CH3COONH4, epoxidation reactions do not take place. Reactions were completed within 5h for MnII-L3imid@Coxand within 1.5h for the MnII-L3imid@PCox catalyst. When alcohol and ketone were detected as allylic oxidation products, the sample was treated with PPh3 and measured again by GC–MS according to Shul’pin’s procedure [67]. In oxidation catalysis with H2O2, this procedure is essential given that there is always the possibility of alkyl hydroperoxides formation. These peroxides can decompose in the case of direct injection to the GC instrument with the formation of the corresponding alcohol and ketone with rapture of CH bonds. As a result, the quantification of alcohol and ketone cannot reflect their real amounts. To be sure that we didn't have these transformations in our catalytic systems, we estimated by GC the concentrations of ketone and alcohol before and after the treatment of the reaction samples with triphenylphosphine. 2.5 General procedure for recycling experiments The first run of the catalytic reactions were performed under the catalytic conditions described above by using cyclooctene as substrate. After the end of each catalytic oxidation which corresponded at 5h for the reactions catalyzed by MnII-L3imid@Coxand 1.5h for those catalyzed by MnII-L3imid@PCox, the solid catalysts were filtered off, washed three times with MeOH and dried under vacuum. The recovered solid catalysts were reused in a next catalytic reaction under the same catalytic conditions. In recycling experiments, it was ensured that the same mass of the solid catalysts was used in each run which was estimated by mass-weighting. This was realized for both catalysts by running 5 identical catalytic batches followed by washing/drying as detailed above. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization Carbon materials with covalently grafted MnII -Schiff base complexes were prepared by the followed synthetic process: i) Oxidation of the activated carbon C and pyrolytic carbon PC with HNO3; ii) generation of the precursor compound L3imid-P which was formed by reaction of the ligand L3imid with the commercial available (3-glycidyloxypropyl)-trimethoxysilane; iii) its metalation with MnII ions salts; and (iv) anchoring of the metalated silane-precursor MnII-L3imid-P onto the oxidized activated Cox and pyrolytic PCox carbon which occurs via hydrolysis and co-condensation reactions with the OH functional groups of the support materials. Scheme 1 displays the synthesis process of the MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox. To prepare active catalytic materials, the immobilization of the preformed Mn-complex is the appropriate way i.e. instead of ligand immobilization and subsequent metalation. This protocol avoids Mn-coordination by free COOH groups of the oxidized supports (Cox and PCox), that would result in unreactive Mn-carboxylate species [25,26]. 3.1.1 FT-IR In Fig. 1 the IR spectra of the pristine materials, oxidized materials and synthesized catalysts are showed. In more details, when the IR spectra of the oxidised materials Cox and PCox are compared to the parent carbon supports C and PC respectively, new bands are observed attributable to the formed COOH surface groups. More specifically, in the spectra of Cox and PCox the bands observed at 1715, and 1176cm−1 for Cox and at 1704, and 1106cm−1 for PCox are assigned to ν(C O) and ν(CO) stretching vibrations, respectively. The IR spectral data indicate the successful formation of COOH. Accordingly, the IR spectra of MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox (Fig. 1) show several bands corresponding to various structural units of the solid support as well as from the ligand L3imid. The v(CN) and v(NH) stretching vibrations respectively are shifted when compared with the corresponding spectrum of the organic ligand L3imid [18]. This indicates coordination of manganese with the imine-nitrogen and the imidazole groups of the immobilized ligand L3imid (Fig. 1). 3.1.2 TGA The derivative thermogram of activated carbon Cox show a broad peak in the range of 80–450°C assigned to the decomposition of COOH surface groups with a 10.0% weight loss and an intense peak at 600°C assigned to the combustion of carbon support. The formed COOH groups are ca. 2.2mmolg−1 (Table 1 ). For pyrolytic carbon PCox the peak which observed in the range of 80–450°C was assigned to the decomposition of COOH surface groups as well with a 10.8% weight loss;thus, theresulted COOH groups are ca. 2.4mmolg−1(Table 1). The thermograms of pristine Cox and PCox materials show a 10.0% and 10.8% weight-loss in the range of 70–400°C attributable to the decomposition of surface COOH groups, while the MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox show a 18.8% and 25.0%, weight loss respectively in the same temperature range; this additional weight loss of 8.8% and 14.2% is assigned to the decomposition of the anchored organic ligand L3imid moieties. The total combustion of MnII-L3imid@Cox corresponds to 93.9% total weight loss and the obtained solid residue of 6.1% is assigned to inorganic salts (3.6%), SiO2 (1.1%) and MnO2(1.4%). The loading achieved is ca. 0.16mmolg−1 determined by thermogravimetric and elemental analysis. Accordingly, the combustion of MnII-L3imid@PCox provides a total weight loss of 87.5% and the obtained solid residue of 12.5% corresponds to inorganic salts (9.2%), SiO2(1.6%) and MnO2(1.7%). The loading achieved is ca. 0.19mmolg−1 determined by thermogravimetric and elemental analysis. 3.1.3 Surface area-porosity The Nitrogen physisorption isotherms for C and Cox are shown in Fig. 2 (A) where volume of nitrogen adsorbed and desorbed are plotted against the relative pressure P/Po. According to IUPAC classification the isotherms of C and Cox samples can be classified as a mixture of I and II type [68,69]. Such behaviour is characteristic of penetration in micropores followed by a monolayer multilayer adsorption and interparticle capillary condensation [70]. The specific surface area calculated using BET method was found to be equal to 857m2/g and 758m2/g for C and Cox respectively. Accordingly, the pore volume by nitrogen adsorption was measured 0.56cm3/g and 0.49cm3/g. The pore size distribution of C and Cox, see inset in Fig. 2(A),was calculated with BJH method. This distribution curve indicates one sharp peak at pore radius ∼19Å, which shows the microporous character of the two samples. The isotherm of MnII-L3imid@Cox which was prepared after grafting of the entire MnII-L3imid-complex onto Cox indicates a non-porous material, see Table 1. The specific surface area shows a dramatic collapse, e.g., from 758m2 g−1 in activated carbon Cox to 53m2 g−1 in MnII-L3imid@Cox (Table 1). The isotherms of PC, PCox and MnII-L3imid@PCox (Fig. 2(B)) are type II, indicating nonporous materials; the specific surface area is 22, 35 and 42m2 g−1, respectively. The observed slight increase in the surface area could be attributed to the change of the size of the bulk grains caused during the treatment with HNO3 and the grafting procedure. 3.1.4 XRD Fig. 3 (A) shows the XRD patterns obtained for the activated carbon-based materials, i.e. C, Cox, and MnII-L3imid@Cox. All diffractograms display two intense doublet feature centered at 2θ∼25° and 43°, characteristic of a disordered carbonaceous structure [71]. The peaks observed exactly at 26.4°, 43.3° and 44.0° are assigned to the (002), (100) and (101) reflections, respectively, of the graphitic part of the materials [71], i.e. the (002) one is due to the stacking structure of aromatic layers while the (100) formed by sp2 hybridized carbons [71]. The 24.4° reflection witnesses the packing distance of saturated structures i.e. such as aliphatic side chains attached at the edge of coal crystallites [72]. The observed XRD patterns suggest that all the studied materials have structures intermediate between graphite and amorphous carbon i.e. called turbostratic structure or random layer lattice structure [72]. Fig. 3(B) shows the XRD patterns obtained for the materials PC, PCox, and MnII-L3imid@PCox. Two non-splitted diffraction peaks at 25.0° and 43.0° were observed on the all the pyrolytic-based carbon materials, corresponding to the (002) and (100/101) planes of the hexagonal graphite [73]. The width of the peaks indicates disordered sp2/sp3carbon structures between the graphitic layers for all samples. However, in case of pristine PC the pattern exhibits additional peaks attributable to inorganic components, i.e. ZnS and ZnO originating from the tires manufacturing. For comparison, a literature XRD pattern for ZnO is superposed in Fig. 3(B) [74]. Upon HNO3 treatment of PC, these additional bands disappear from the diffractogram of the oxidized char PCox, which now appears to be identical to MnII-L3imid@PCox. The broadening and slight decrease in the intensity of the peak at 2θ∼44° of the layered graphitic sp2-domains of MnII-L3imid@PCox as well as of MnII-L3imid@Cox vs. the corresponding peak of PCox or Cox confirms the successful modification of the Cox and the PCox matrices by the [MnII-L3imid] catalytic component. This is further supported by the XRD patterns of both MnII-L3imid@PCox and MnII-L3imid@Cox which do not contain sharp peaks from non-immobilized crystallites of the [MnII-L3imid] complex. 3.1.5 Raman Raman spectra of the C, Cox and MnII-L3imid@Cox are shown in Fig. 4 (A). All spectra exhibit two intense peaks, the D band assigned to carbon atoms with sp3 hybridization due to defects or distortion of the crystal lattice and the G band attributed to an active vibration E2g of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms. For the pristine C, the G band shows at 1601cm−1 while the D band at 1353cm−1. Τhe intensity of ID/IG ratio is equal to 0.93. After the oxidation treatment, the intensity of the D band increases in the spectrum of Cox; this is attributed to the increase of the sp3carbons, resulting in disorder of the Cox. Τhe intensity of ID/IG ratio increases now to 0.98. In the spectrum of the MnII-L3imid@Cox,the intensity of G band remains stable while the intensity of the D band increases. The ID/IG ratio increases from 0.98 for Cox to 1.05 for MnII-L3imid@Cox, suggesting an increase at the concentration of the structural defects, probable due to the formation of new bonds between the carbon matrix and the active catalytic component [MnII-L3imid]. The Raman spectra of PC, PCox and MnII-L3imid@PCox are shown in Fig. 4(B). The intensity ratio of PC is ID/IG =0.69.The G band shows at 1585cm−1 while the D band at 1348cm−1. Upon oxidation treatment (PCox spectrum) and grafting procedure (MnII-L3imid@PCox spectrum) the intensity of both peaks (G and D band) at 1589cm−1, 1380cm−1 and 1589cm−1, 1354cm−1 are decreased resulting in intensity ratio ID/IG =0.77 and ID/IG =0.83 respectively. Overall, these findings suggest well-accomplished oxidation and functionalization procedures of the pristine PC material resulting in increase of sp3-hybridised carbon defect sites. In summary, based on these data, the ID/IG ratios follow the order (ID/IG)C <(ID/IG)Cox <(ID/IG)Mn-L3imid@Coxand(ID/IG)PC <(ID/IG)PCox <(ID/IG)Mn-L3imid@PCox clearly indicating that any chemical treatment of the pristine materials decreases their graphitic sp2 character. Comparing the ID/IG ratio of activated vs. pyrolytic carbon for any chemical process, we observed that always (ID/IG)activatedcarbon > (ID/IG)pyrolyticcarbon , e.g. (ID/IG)C>(ID/IG)PC, (ID/IG)Cox>(ID/IG)PCox and (ID/IG)Mn-L3imid@Cox >(ID/IG)Mn-L3imid@PCox. This indicates that commercial activated carbon bears more sp3 carbon atoms i.e. as confirmed also by XRD. Thus, the low content of such aliphatic structures into the pyrolytic matrixes suggests that −probably– they did not survive during pyrolysis. 3.1.6 SEM Representative SEM images of the pristine matrices, acid activated samples and catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . Significant differences between the surface topography of C and PC carbon are observed in SEM (Fig. 5a, d); activated carbon C has a more multilayered structure than the pyrolytic carbon PC which seems to be smoother probably due to the transformation of its morphology during pyrolysis. Moreover, it is observed that both pristine matrices have irregular shape. SEM images of HNO3-treated samples are shown in Fig. 5b, e; it is evident that this treatment does not significantly affect the surface of Cox, since no obvious morphological and textural changes are observed vs. C; however, PCox particles are smoother than the pristine PC particles. Fig. 5c, f displays SEM images of the catalytic materials MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox. Covalent anchoring of the active catalytic component [MnII-L3imid] onto the Cox and PCox caused a significant cracking of the particles, i.e. Fig. 5C reveals the presence of smaller particles. The morphology of the surface is slightly different, and it is clear that after the anchoring procedure the surface of the particles became smoother. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation 3.2.1 Products’ detection and quantification The catalytic behavior of the MnII-L3imid@Cox was investigated in olefin epoxidation by H2O2 and then compared to that of MnII-L3imid@PCox under identical conditions (Table 2 ). The present carbon-based heterogeneous catalysts, to become active for alkene epoxidation with H2O2 require ammonium acetate as additive in analogous way to other non-heme Mn-catalysts [18,25,26,50]. This is attributed to a dual acid-base behavior of CH3COONH4 by acting as proton-donor and proton-acceptor [18,67,75]. More precisely, according to the catalytic mechanism which was proposed by us recently [i] CH3COO−abstracts proton from H2O2 promoting its coordination to MnII and the formation of MnII-OOH species and [ii] subsequently, NH4 +, by acting as a proton donor to MnII-OOH, accelerates heterolytic OO cleavage forming the active MnIV =O species which [iii] catalyzes alkene epoxidation [25]. The catalytic oxidations were carried out at room temperature in acetone:MeOH (v/v=450μl/400μl) solution and the used molar ratio of catalyst:H2O2:CH3COONH4: substrate was equal to 1:2000:1000:1000 (μmoles). According to Table 2, epoxidation of wide range of olefins proceeds with high conversion and selectivity for the epoxide product (the mass balance is 98–100%) in most of the cases (Table 2). To ensure that the observed catalytic results were derived by the heterogeneous catalysts and no leaching of the active catalytic component occurs during the catalytic processes, control experiments were carried out. Specifically, a possible leaching of the Mn(II)-complexes from the carbon support was tested by the ‘filtration method' according to M.H. Valkenberg, W.F. Holderich [76]. In typical catalytic experiments after 30min the solid catalysts were filtered; the catalytic reaction of the filtrate's solution was monitored by GC [53]. The data showed that no evolution of the studied reactions was observed in the filtrate. This ensures that no leaching of the active Mn(II)-catalyst occurs substantiating that the obtained catalytic results derive exclusively from the heterogeneous catalysts. Based on our catalytic data provided in Table 2, in the epoxidation of cyclooctene by MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox, cis-cyclooctene epoxide (9-oxabicyclo[6.1.0]nonane) was the main product with a 100% selectivity and 60.7 and 75.6% yield respectively (Fig. 6 ). In the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexene, cyclohexene oxide (7-oxabicyclo[4.1.0]heptane) was clearly the major product (yields 82.7 and 51.5%); however, small amounts of allylic oxidation products such as has cyclohex-2-en-1-ol (0.6, 1.9%) and cyclohex-2-en-1-one (3.5, 2.9%) have been also detected. It is clarified that the quantified amounts of cyclohex-2-en-1-ol and cyclohex-2-en-1-one are identical to those obtained after a PPh3-treatment according the Shul’pins’ procedure [67] which ensures that putative hydroperoxides formed during catalysis as primary products have been completely transformed into the corresponding alcohol/ketone [67–75,77]. Hex-1-ene, which is a rather hard oxidation substrate, showed epoxide yield from 11.3-16.3%. The epoxidation of trans-β-methylstyrene ((1E)-1-Propen-1-ylbenzene), cis-stilbene ((Z)-stilbene), styrene and cyclopentene produces only the corresponding epoxides with a 100% selectivity, demonstrating that the olefin epoxidation by MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox is highly stereospecific resulting in yields of [53.3%, 46.1%], [51.7%, 33.3%], [58.1%, 48%] and [22.5%, 62.6%] respectively. Two epoxides (cis- and trans-) were the main products derived from epoxidation of the electron-rich double bond in 1,2-position of limonene ((4R)-1-methyl-4-prop-1-en-2-ylcyclohexene). The total yield of 1, 2-epoxides was 67.5% and 81.4% catalysed by MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox, respectively. Small amounts of the alcohols p-mentha-1,8-dien-2-ol (1-methyl-4-prop-1-en-2-ylcyclohex-2-en-1-ol) and p-mentha-2,8-dien-1-ol ((3R,6S)-3-methyl-6-prop-1-en-2-ylcyclohexen-1-ol) formed by allylic oxidation of the limonene ring have also been observed and have been identified (11.6–15.5%). The formation of epoxides derived from the more accessible but less electron-rich double bond in 8,9-position has not been observed. Thus, the epoxidation was clearly the main reaction path resulting mainly in 1,2-epoxides (see Table 2, Fig. 6). In the oxidation of alpha-pinene (4,6,6-trimethylbicyclo[3.1.1]hept-3-ene) catalysed by MnII-L3imid@Cox, the main product was the epoxide with 40% yield; when the MnII-L3imid@PCox used as catalyst, the epoxide yield found to be 57.4% and small amounts of 2-pinen-4-ol(4.1%) and 3-pinanone (3.1%) have been also detected. MnII-L3imid@Cox exhibited higher catalytic activity towards the oxidation of 1-methyl-1-cyclohexene resulting in yield 77.4% (100% selectivity) compared to 54.1% of the reaction catalyzed by MnII-L3imid@PCox which provided also small amounts of ketone (0.5%) and allyl alcohol (3.3%). Evaluating the catalytic performance of the catalysts MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox based on the achieved TONs, we do not observe a clear superiority of any of them (Table 2, Fig. 7 ). 3.2.2 Kinetic Data The time-depended cyclooctene oxidation catalyzed by the heterogeneous catalysts, in conjunction with the observed redox potential of solution Eh (vs. standard hydrogen electrode SHE) are shown in Fig. 8 . At the beginning of the reaction catalyzed by MnII-L3imid@Cox, Eh was +337mV; after 1h, it dropped at +225mV with a 27% epoxide yield and finally, after a reaction time of 5h, it approached a value of Eh =+230mV with 60.7% yield. In the case of MnII-L3imid@PCox – catalyzed epoxidation, at reaction time t=0, Ehwas+338mV, at t=1h it decreased at +210mV providing a product yield of 65% and at t=1.5h, Eh approached +205mV with a 75.6% cyclooctene epoxide formation. Analogous kinetic profiles were observed for all the studied substrates. Thus overall, oxidations catalysed by MnII-L3imid@Cox were practically accomplished within 5h and reactions catalysed by MnII-L3imid@PCoxwere accomplished within 1.5h. The resulting TOFs, listed in Table 2, visualised in Fig. 9 , clearly demonstrate the superiority of MnII-L3imid@PCox vs. the MnII-L3imid@Cox. Notice that the TOFs achieved by MnII-L3imid@PCox ranged from 109 to 646h−1 while the TOFs by MnII-L3imid@Cox was by far inferior, ranging from 22 to 174h−1. 3.2.3 Catalytic Recycling The heterogeneous catalysts MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox were tested for their recyclability by repeated recovering and reusing of the solid catalysts in new catalytic reactions. As pilot reaction, the catalytic oxidation of cyclooctene was chosen and a [catalyst: H2O2: cyclooctene: additive: CH3COONH4]=[1:2000:1000:1000] molar ratio was used in an acetone/MeOH (450μl/400μl) solvent mixture. After each catalytic run, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed, dried and reused under the same catalytic conditions. The recycling catalytic data for both MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox are displayed in Fig. 10 . According to Fig. 10 MnII-L3imid@Cox presented a good reusability especially during a second run showing a ∼20% loss of the catalytic activity during the 2th run and >50% loss of the activity for each of the following re-uses. MnII-L3imid@PCox is able to work only for a single run presenting a total loss of its catalytic activity (>90%) during the 2nd re-use. In total, MnII-L3imid@Cox provided 1300 TONs for cyclooctene oxidation instead of 831 TONs by MnII-L3imid@PCox. This behaviour is assigned to oxidative destruction of the active catalytic component [MnII-L3imid] during catalysis [78]; the majority of the MnII-centrers are still associated to the carbonaceous matrices after the 1st run for MnII-L3imid@PCox and the 2nd for MnII-L3imid@Cox, however, they do not show the specific coordination environment of [MnII-L3imid] in analogous way, as we have shown vey recently [78] using EPR spectroscopy. Thus, the much higher TOFs and efficiency of MnII-L3imid@PCox vs. MnII-L3imid@Cox is counteracted by its higher auto-oxidation rate. 5 Conclusion Covalent immobilisation of a catalytically active [MnII-L3imid] complexon the surface of commercial available activated and pyrolytic carbon has been achieved. The ligand L3imid bears a Schiff base backbone and three imidazole residues. The preformed [MnII-L3imid] complex was transformed into a silane-precursor MnII-L3imid-P which was grafted onto oxidized activated Cox or pyrolytic PCox carbon via sol-gel type chemistry, resulting in the MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox functionalized materials. Both hybrids are non-porous materials with disordered sp2/sp3graphitic carbon structures. Cox bears more sp3 carbon atoms vs. PCox indicating that, for the pyrolytic matrixes, these aliphatic structures did not survive during pyrolysis. Raman shows (ID/IG)activatedcarbon > (ID/IG)pyrolyticcarbon , indicating higher graphitic character of pyrolytic carbon than the activated carbon. Accordingly, further chemical treatment of Cox and PCox materials decreased their graphitic character, retaining however, the general order (ID/IG)activatedcarbon >(ID/IG)pyrolyticcarbon. Noticeably, under chemical treatment, the particles became smoother and significant cracking occurred. Both MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox showed high selectivity towards epoxides. However, MnII-L3imid@PCox catalyst is kinetically faster (1.5h vs. 5h) than the MnII-L3imid@Cox resulting in extremely higher TOFs vs. MnII-L3imid@Cox. In terms of recyclability, MnII-L3imid@Cox can reused for a 2th run showing a ∼20% loss of its catalytic activity, while MnII-L3imid@PCox was practically no recyclable. Thus, the much higher rapidity and efficiency of MnII-L3imid@PCox vs. the MnII-L3imid@Cox is counter paid by higher oxidative destruction. coredata.dc:description: Two types of heterogeneous catalytic materials, MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox, have been synthesized and compared by covalent grafting of a catalytically active [MnII-L3imid] complex on the surface of an oxidized activated carbon (Cox) and an oxidized pyrolytic carbon from recycled-tire char (PCox). Both hybrids are non-porous bearing graphitic layers intermixed with disordered sp2/sp3 carbon units. Raman spectra show that (ID/IG)activatedcarbon >(ID/IG)pyrolyticcarbon revealing that oxidized activated carbon(Cox) is less graphitized than oxidized pyrolytic carbon (PCox). The MnII-L3imid@Cox and MnII-L3imid@PCox catalysts were evaluated for alkene oxidation with H2O2 in the presence of CH3COONH4. Both showed high selectivity towards epoxides and comparing the achieved yields and TONs, they appear equivalent. However, MnII-L3imid@PCox catalyst is kinetically faster than the MnII-L3imid@Cox (accomplishing the catalytic runs in 1.5h vs. 5h). Thus, despite the similarity in TONs MnII-L3imid@PCox achieved extremely higher TOFs vs. MnII-L3imid@Cox. Intriguingly, in terms of recyclability, MnII-L3imid@Cox could be reused for a 2th run showing a ∼20% loss of its catalytic activity, while MnII-L3imid@PCox practically no recyclable. This phenomenon is discussed in a mechanistic context; interlinking oxidative destruction of the Mn-complex with high TOFs for MnII-L3imid@PCox, while the low-TOFs of MnII-L3imid@Cox are preventive for the oxidative destruction of the Mn-complex.
coredata.dc:title: Activated vs. pyrolytic carbon as support matrix for chemical functionalization: Efficient heterogeneous non-heme Mn(II) catalysts for alkene oxidation with H2O2
